slides.title: What is Blade? ‚öîÔ∏è
slides.content:
# Simple & Powerful

Laravel's templating engine.

Blade files use `.blade.php` extension.

Unlike other PHP templating engines, Blade does not restrict you from using plain PHP code in your views.

slides.title: Displaying Data
slides.content:
# Curly Braces üêö

Display a variable passed from a route/controller.

`Hello, {{ $name }}.`

Automatically escapes data to prevent XSS.

`{!! $html !!}` to output raw HTML (careful!).

slides.title: Components
slides.content:
# Modern Reusability üß©

Like Vue/React components but server-side.

`<x-alert type="error" :message="$message" />`

Defined in `resources/views/components/alert.blade.php`.

slides.title: Included Views
slides.content:
# Partials ü§è

Include a smaller view into a larger one.

`@include('shared.errors')`

Great for headers, footers, or navigation bars.

slides.title: Stacks
Service Injection
slides.content:
# @inject üíâ Retrieve a service directly in the template. `@inject('metrics', 'App\Services\MetricsService')` `
Monthly Revenue: {{ $metrics->monthlyRevenue() }}
`

slides.title: Comments
slides.content:
# Secret Notes ü§´

Blade comments are NOT rendered in the final HTML.

`{{-- This comment will not be present in the rendered HTML --}}`

Unlike `<!-- HTML comments -->` which act essentially as visibility: hidden.

slides.title: Summary
slides.content:
# Recap: Blade üó°Ô∏è

Front-end logic.

- **Output:** `{{ }}`.
- **Directives:** `@if`, `@foreach`.
- **Layouts:** `@extends`, `@section`.
- **Components:** `<x-button />`.
